If the ground is too hard to dig into, one alternative way to plant a garden would be to use raised garden beds. These are boxes or containers filled with soil that can be placed on top of the hard ground. This allows for easier access to the soil and also allows for better drainage and aeration.

Another option would be to use a hydroponic system. In this method, plants are grown in a nutrient-rich solution rather than in soil. This eliminates the need to dig into the ground and allows for easier maintenance of the garden.

If the ground is too hard to dig into, it may be necessary to use a different type of soil or amendments. For example, adding organic matter such as compost or aged manure can help to improve the texture and fertility of the soil, making it easier to work with.
Another option would be to use a soil aerator to break up the hard ground. This tool uses spikes to puncture the soil and improve its structure, making it easier to work with.

If the ground is too hard to dig into, it may be necessary to use a different type of planting method. For example, some plants, such as succulents and cacti, can be planted using a method called "rock gardening," where the plants are placed directly on the ground without soil. This method can be effective in areas with hard, rocky soil.
